Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't indicate the true relationship between the two sentences. “Regardless” means in spite of something. This transition does not indicate that an example will follow.
This choice doesn't indicate the true relationship between the two sentences. “However” indicates a contrast. This transition does not indicate that an example will follow.
This choice doesn't indicate the true relationship between the two sentences. “Furthermore” means in addition. This transition does not indicate that an example will follow.

The prepositional phrase “for example” logically connects the two sentences and correctly indicates that what follows in the second sentence will be examples of household waste products: paper, glass, aluminum, and garbage.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision best maintains the style and tone of the passage?

Key.Rationale: Although all the choices mean “to get rid of,” their connotations are different. “Annihilating” is usually used to refer to the act of completely destroying, which is too intense in this context. This expression doesn't fit the tone of the passage and is not idiomatic when used with “need.”
The verb “eliminate” means to remove, and it makes the most sense in the sentence because the object of the verb is “need.” “Eliminating the need” is an idiomatic expression for “removing the need.”

Although all the choices mean “to get rid of,” their connotations are different. “Ousting” is generally used when referring to the act of forcibly removing a person from a position. This expression doesn't fit the tone of the passage and is not idiomatic when used with “need.”

Although all the choices mean “to get rid of,” their connotations are different. “Closing the door on” is a colloquial expression that usually means shutting out the possibility of something happening or not being willing to consider an idea. This expression doesn't fit the tone of the passage and is not idiomatic when used with “need.”

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L3 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The use of the pronoun “it” to begin new independent clauses creates comma splices.
“Savings increase” doesn't maintain the parallel structure of the verbs in the sentence: “minimizes water waste and storm runoff” and “helps reduce erosion.”

The singular present tense verb “increases” agrees in number with the singular noun “compost” and maintains the parallel structure of the other two compound verbs in the sentence, “minimizes” and “helps.”
The use of the pronoun “also it” to begin new independent clauses creates comma splices.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The initial parenthesis is missing and no comma is needed between the noun “quantities” and the modifying information.
When setting off nonessential information, a pair of parentheses needs to be used. This choice provides the initial parenthesis that the parenthesis after “municipality” requires.
The initial parenthesis is missing.
No semicolon is needed before the parenthetical information.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
The writer wants to include information from the graph that is consistent with the description of compost in the passage. Which revision most effectively accomplishes this goal?

Key.Rationale: The passage thus far has focused on compost. Metal is not a material that is composted.

B.Choice: 6 million tons of rubber and leather

Key.Rationale: The passage thus far has focused on compost. Rubber & leather are not materials that are composted.
The passage thus far has focused on compost. Textiles are not materials that are composted.
According to the information from the graph, 33 million tons of food waste were discarded in US landfills in 2009, which is consistent with the discussion of food waste in the passage.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
The writer wants to support the paragraph's main idea with accurate, relevant information from the graph. Which revision most effectively accomplishes this goal?

Key.Rationale: This choice is not true, according to the graph. The graph indicates that less glass was discarded in the landfills than plastics and paper.
This choice is not true, according to the graph. The graph indicates that less metal was discarded in the landfills than plastics and paper.
According to the graph, this is the only choice that makes the sentence true. More food waste was discarded in landfills in 2009 “than any other substance, including plastics or paper.”
This choice is not true, according to the graph. The graph indicates that less yard waste was discarded in the landfills than plastics and paper.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The word “then” indicates “when” and is not used in comparisons.
No comma is needed between the comparative adjective “worse” and the comparative conjunction “than.”
The word “then” indicates “when” and is not used in comparisons.
No comma is needed after worse.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L8 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “Contribute” is a plural present tense verb.
“Are contributing” is a plural present tense verb.
The present tense singular verb “contributes” agrees in number with the singular noun “material,” and the present tense verb is consistent with the other present tense verbs in the passage.
“Have contributed” is a plural past tense verb.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L9 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “Potent” means strong or powerful, which makes sense in the context of discussing greenhouse gas.
“Sturdy” is usually used to refer to the physical strength or solidity of something.
“Influential” refers to the power of a person to affect or sway others or events without any apparent effort.
“Commanding” indicates that the inanimate greenhouse gas is actually commanding something.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L10 of the passage.
Which revision provides the most effective transition from the previous paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice does not offer a transition that indicates a connection between the problem identified in the previous paragraph—the release of dangerous methane gas from the compost in landfills—and the concluding paragraph that identifies what some cities have done to help alleviate the problem.

This choice does not offer a transition that indicates a connection between the problem identified in the previous paragraph—the release of dangerous methane gas from the compost in landfills—and the concluding paragraph that identifies what some cities have done to help alleviate the problem.

“Armed with these facts” is the most effective transition from the previous paragraph, which discusses the amounts of various substances that end up in landfills and the resulting methane gas that is released from the organic matter. The paragraph that this transition introduces goes on to discuss laws that some cities have instituted to control the handling of compost in landfills to reduce the release of methane gas.

This choice does not offer a transition that indicates a connection between the problem identified in the previous paragraph—the release of dangerous methane gas from the compost in landfills—and the concluding paragraph that identifies what some cities have done to help alleviate the problem.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: No change is needed because the correlative conjunctions “either” and “or” are used together to indicate that one choice or another should be considered. In this sentence, residents are encouraged to choose the option to create their own compost piles or to dispose of compostable materials in bins for collection.
This choice does not provide the correlating conjunction for “either” used earlier in the sentence.
This choice does not provide the correlating conjunction for “either” used earlier in the sentence.
This choice does not provide the correlating conjunction for “either” used earlier in the sentence.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively combines the sentences at the emphasized portion?

Key.Rationale: The sentences are effectively combined by placing a comma after “red” and making the second sentence an appositive that explains the significance of the color red.
This choice contains excessive words that add no meaning to the resulting sentence.

C.Choice: red; in other words, red is

Key.Rationale: This choice contains excessive words that add no meaning to the resulting sentence.
This choice contains excessive words that add no meaning to the resulting sentence.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: No commas are needed after “festive” and “red” because the adjectives don't equally modify “banners.” No comma is needed after “banners” because there is no reason to put one between “banners” and “and garlands,” the two objects of the preposition “with.”
Placing commas  around the prepositional phrase “with festive red banners” wrongly indicates that the information is nonessential and could be eliminated without changing the meaning of the sentence.
There should not be a dash or any other kind of punctuation between “banners” and “and garlands.”
Punctuation is not necessary in the emphasized portion of the sentence.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L3 of the passage.
Which revision mos effectively completes the explanation of a possible origin of the lion dance?

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't make a connection between the fierce quality of a lion and scaring away spirits.

B.Choice: the evil spirit was called Nian.

Key.Rationale: The name of the spirit is not as important as why a lion was incorporated into the dance.

C.Choice: villagers dressed in lion costumes to scare the spirit away.

Key.Rationale: This choice expands on the idea that the lion dance may have originated to ward off an evil spirit and that dressing in a lion costume was part of the effort to scare the spirit away.

D.Choice: the precise location of the village remains lost to history.

Key.Rationale: The location of the village where the dance originated is not as important as why a lion was incorporated into the dance.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively concludes the paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't effectively bring the paragraph to a conclusion. This choice is vague and calls for elaboration - it lacks specific information.

B.Choice: It turns out that the origins of the lion dance are irrelevant.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't effectively bring the paragraph to a conclusion. This choice is vague and calls for elaboration - it lacks proof for the idea of irrelevance.

C.Choice: Whatever its origins, today the lion dance is a joyous spectacle, a celebration of the promise of the New Year.

Key.Rationale: It ties the information about the possible origins and historical purpose of the lion dance to its present purpose as a New Year's celebration of hope.

D.Choice: Things are different these days, of course.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't effectively bring the paragraph to a conclusion. This choice is vague and calls for elaboration - it lacks a connection to the subject of the paragraph.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The pronoun “both” and prepositional phrase “of whom” refer to “dancers” and are used correctly to introduce a clause that describes how the dancers are hidden by the lion costume. “Whom” is used correctly as the object of the preposition “of.”
The word order doesn't make grammatical sense and the pronoun “which” can't be used to refer to people.
This choice creates a comma splice.
This choice creates a comma splice.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not compare similar things. “Moves” can't be compared to “martial arts” or “acrobatics.”

B.Choice: the disciplines of martial arts and acrobatics.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not compare similar things. “Moves” can't be compared to “martial arts,” “acrobatics,” or “disciplines.”
This choice does not compare similar things. “Moves” can't be compared to “martial artists” or “acrobats.”

D.Choice: those in martial arts and acrobatics

Key.Rationale: The pronoun “those” correctly indicates that the moves in dance are being compared to the moves in martial arts. “Those” takes the place of the noun “moves” in the comparison.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision provides information that is most consistent in style and content with the information about the symbolism of the tortoise?

Key.Rationale: The parenthetical information indicates what a phoenix is, not what it represents. Furthermore, the information is not presented in a prepositional phrase.

This choice indicates that the phoenix represents new beginnings, which is consistent in content with the information explaining that the tortoise represents longevity. Additionally, this choice is presented as a parenthetical prepositional phrase beginning with the preposition “for,” which is consistent in structure with the parenthetical prepositional phrase “for longevity.”
This choice indicates the source of the phoenix, not what it represents.
This choice is vague and doesn't identify what the phoenix symbolizes.

Content: Refer to location L8 of the passage and think about the passage as a whole.
To make this paragraph most logical, sentence 5 should be placed

Key.Rationale: Placing sentence 5 after any other sentence in the paragraph would not be logical and would interrupt the flow of the passage.
Placing sentence 5 after any other sentence in the paragraph would not be logical and would interrupt the flow of the passage.
Placing sentence 5 after any other sentence in the paragraph would not be logical and would interrupt the flow of the passage.

Sentence 5 most logically should follow sentence 7. The pronoun “their” in sentence 5 refers to the “black lions” (which are the youngest lions and dance quickly) in sentence 7. Sentence 5 indicates that the “older counterparts” to the young lions don't move as quickly.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L9 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “It's” is the contraction for “it is” and doesn't make sense in the sentence.
The singular possessive pronoun “its” agrees in number with the singular antecedent “dance” and correctly indicates that the “climax” belongs to the dance.
“There” is not a possessive pronoun.
“Their” is a plural possessive pronoun that doesn't agree with the singular antecedent “dance.”

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L10 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The teeth don't do the approaching; only an animate object can do that.

B.Choice: lion snares the envelope with its teeth.

Key.Rationale: This choice correctly indicates that the lion is doing the approaching and the snaring, not the teeth.

C.Choice: envelope is snared by the lion with its teeth.

Key.Rationale: This choice is written in the passive voice, which changes the subject of the sentence from “lion” to “envelope.” Furthermore, an “envelope” cannot approach a doorway.

D.Choice: teeth of the lion snare the envelope.

Key.Rationale: The teeth don't do the snaring; only an animate object can do that.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and contains information that has been given previously in the paragraph. Additionally, this choice contains inaccurate information because once the money has been chewed up, the envelope is no longer “money-filled.”

B.Choice: envelope that had been dangling from the doorway.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and contains information that has been given previously in the paragraph.

C.Choice: envelope that had the money in it.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and contains information that has been given previously in the paragraph.
The single word “envelope” is concise and clearly refers to the envelope that has been described earlier in the paragraph.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision best fits with the tone of the rest of the passage?

Key.Rationale: No change is needed because “scrupulous” fits the formal tone of the passage. “Scrupulous” means exact and conscientious, and it is appropriate when discussing notes taken during a court proceeding.
This choice is too informal and therefore do not fit the tone of the passage.
This choice is too informal and therefore do not fit the tone of the passage.
“Intense” is an adjective that is used to describe something that is done to an extreme degree, such as putting forth effort or performing a physical act.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice contains semicolons either after “hearings.” Semicolons can be used to separate items in a series that already contains commas, but not to separate individual items in a simple series of words or phrases.

This choice contains semicolons both after “hearings” and “depositions.” Semicolons can be used to separate items in a series that already contains commas, but not to separate individual items in a simple series of words or phrases.
Commas after “hearings” and “depositions” are correct because they separate the first two items in a series of three.

This choice contains a semicolons either after “depositions.” Semicolons can be used to separate items in a series that already contains commas, but not to separate individual items in a simple series of words or phrases.

Content: At this point, the writer is considering adding the following graph.
problems/SAT18RW2/media/25a.jpg
Should the writer make this addition here?

A.Choice: Yes, because it supports the claim that court reporting is an important part of a trial.

Key.Rationale: The graph should not be added. It does not support the claim that court reporting is an important part of a trial.

B.Choice: Yes, because it offers a relevant counterpoint to the argument that the use of digital recorders is on the rise.

Key.Rationale: The graph should not be added. It does not offer a relevant counterpoint to the argument that the use of digital recorders is on the rise.

C.Choice: No, because it presents information that is not directly related to the paragraph's discussion of the role of court reporters.

Key.Rationale: The graph should not be added because it doesn't support the information in the paragraph. The paragraph describes what a court reporter does. The graph provides information that compares the median salary of court reporters to that of other jobs.

D.Choice: No, because it does not provide information about the pay scale for more experienced court reporters.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't matter that there is no information provided in the graph about the pay scale for more experienced court reporters. The paragraph doesn't deal with the subject of pay, so therefore the graph doesn't support the paragraph.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: No change needs to be made because the word “to” is the idiomatic preposition to connect “subject” with the phrase “human errors” to show that technology such as a digital recorder doesn't make the same mistakes that people make, such as “mishearing or mistyping.”
The verb “subjected” is a transitive verb that requires a direct object, which is not present in the sentence. Furthermore, “subjected from” is not idiomatic.
The verb “subjected” is a transitive verb that requires a direct object, which is not present in the sentence. Furthermore, “subjected from” is not idiomatic.
“Subject for human errors” doesn't make sense.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: The singular “record keeper” can't be used to refer to plural “court reporters.”
The word “each” is unnecessary and makes the sentence confusing.

The preposition “as” means “functioning in the same way” or “in the capacity of.” The plural noun “record keepers” agrees in number with the plural noun “court reporters.” The sentence indicates that court reporters are functioning as record keepers.
The singular “record keeper” can't be used to refer to plural “court reporters.” Additionally, in this choice the infinitive verb phrase “to be” can't be used in place of a preposition.

Content: Refer to location L6 of the passage and think about the passage as a whole.
To make this paragraph most logical, sentence 6 should be placed

Key.Rationale: Placing sentence 6 after any other sentence would not be logical and would interrupt the flow of the paragraph.
Placing sentence 6 after any other sentence would not be logical and would interrupt the flow of the paragraph.

To make the paragraph most logical, sentence 6 should be placed after sentence 3. Sentence 3 explains that the words the recorder types are “instantaneously” available to a judge to view on a computer screen. Sentence 6 explains, by using the transition “however,” that even though words are available instantly, recording technology continues to improve and therefore the need for court reporters is decreasing.
Placing sentence 6 after any other sentence would not be logical and would interrupt the flow of the paragraph.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively combines the sentences at the emphasized portion?

Key.Rationale: The word “such” indicates incorrectly that an example of something will follow it.

The dash most effectively combines the two sentences. It correctly indicates that what follows is explanatory information. In this case, the information after the dash could be inferred from what has already been stated because the opposite of making fewer mistakes is making more mistakes. The information after the dash in this sentence makes the conclusion overt.
This choice is wordy and not as succinct as using a dash.
This choice is wordy and not as succinct as using a dash.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L8 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: A semicolon can't be used to separate a dependent and an independent clause.
The comma is used correctly to separate the introductory dependent clause from the main independent clause that follows it.
A period can't be used at the end of a dependent clause.
The adverb “therefore” doesn't make sense in this context; what follows does not result from something said earlier in the sentence.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L9 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't show the true relationship between the two sentences. “Despite this” means that in spite of something already said, what follows will be the case. This choice does not offer a further explanation of what was previously said.

“In other words” indicates correctly that what follows will be an elaboration of the idea that digital recorders can't distinguish “important parts of the proceedings from other noises in the courtroom,” “such as a book dropping.”

This choice doesn't show the true relationship between the two sentences. “Therefore” indicates that what follows will be the result of something said earlier. This choice does not offer a further explanation of what was previously said.

This choice doesn't show the true relationship between the two sentences. “Consequently” indicates that what follows will be the result of something said earlier. This choice does not offer a further explanation of what was previously said.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L10 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice needlessly repeats “distinguish between.”
This choice is not parallel or grammatical.
This choice is wordy and wrongly suggests that court reporters distinguish between words and a time period (when).

The prepositional phrase “between the words and the extrinsic noises” clearly and concisely identifies what a court reporter is able to distinguish. It is also the only parallel option, using two noun phrases after “between,” which are joined by “and.”

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L11 of the passage.
Which revision provides the best supporting example for the main idea of the paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't support the main idea of the paragraph. Making additional announcements at the beginning of a trial is not an example of what can happen as a result of using digital recorders that can't distinguish words from other courtroom noises.

B.Choice: requires a courtroom monitor to ensure the equipment is functioning properly.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't support the main idea of the paragraph. Monitoring to ensure equipment is functioning properly is not an example of what can happen as a result of using digital recorders that can't distinguish words from other courtroom noises.

C.Choice: leads to changes in the roles and duties of several members of the courtroom staff.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't support the main idea of the paragraph. Changing roles and duties of several members of the courtroom staff is not an example of what can happen as a result of using digital recorders that can't distinguish words from other courtroom noises.

D.Choice: has led to the need for retrial because of indistinct testimony from key witnesses.

Key.Rationale: The main idea of the paragraph is that court reporters can distinguish between words and extraneous noises in the courtroom, which digital recorders can't always do. This choice offers an example of what can go wrong in a courtroom because digital recorders can't always pick up “indistinct testimony”: the need for retrial because of indistinct testimony from witnesses.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L1 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice does not show the true relationship between the information that comes before and what follows the linking adverb. “Moreover” means that additional information will follow. This choice does not indicate the difference between the behaviors of combustion and fire on Earth and in space.
The adverb “however” indicates that regardless of the conditions that affect “combustion and the resulting fire” on Earth, their behavior in space is different.

This choice does not show the true relationship between the information that comes before and what follows the linking adverb. “Accordingly” means that what follows corresponds to what has already been said or that what follows is a consequence. This choice does not indicate the difference between the behaviors of combustion and fire on Earth and in space.

This choice does not show the true relationship between the information that comes before and what follows the linking adverb. “Subsequently” means that what follows happens after what was previously stated. This choice does not indicate the difference between the behaviors of combustion and fire on Earth and in space.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L2 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and the word “biofuel” is not placed immediately in front of the parenthetical information that defines it.

B.Choice: strove for a method to make their study of biofuel combustion

Key.Rationale: This choice is wordy and the word “biofuel” is not placed immediately in front of the parenthetical information that defines it.

C.Choice: looked for a method to study biofuel combustion

Key.Rationale: This choice uses the verb “looked,” which is not preferable to “sought” in this science context.

D.Choice: sought a method to study combustion of biofuels

Key.Rationale: The past tense verb “sought” clearly and concisely conveys the idea that the students were trying to find a method to study combustion of biofuels. Additionally, the word “biofuels” is correctly placed immediately in front of the parenthetical information that defines it to prevent confusion.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L3 of the passage.
Which revision provides the most precise description of the phenomenon depicted in the previous sentence?

Key.Rationale: No change needs to be made because the word “deformation” provides the most precise description of what results when fuel droplets lose their symmetrical form while burning. A droplet that is deformed loses some good attribute due to the influence of some external condition.
“Alteration” imply that something is changed on purpose. This choice is not accurate when discussing the effect of “gravitational influence” and the “movement of molecules” on droplets of fuel.
“Transformation” means that one thing is changed into another. This choice is not accurate when discussing the effect of “gravitational influence” and the “movement of molecules” on droplets of fuel.
“Modification” imply that something is changed on purpose. This choice is not accurate when discussing the effect of “gravitational influence” and the “movement of molecules” on droplets of fuel.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L4 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: “Causes” is a singular verb that doesn't agree in number with the plural pronoun “both.” Additionally, this choice is a present perfect tense verbs that is used to describe a past event that has an influence on the present, which is not the case in this context.

B.Choice: cause uneven heat flow and limit

Key.Rationale: The plural verbs “cause” and “limit” agree in number with the plural pronoun “both,” which refers to the plural noun “variations.”

C.Choice: cause uneven heat flow and limits

Key.Rationale: “Limits” is a singular verb that doesn't agree in number with the plural pronoun “both.”  Additionally, this choice is a present perfect tense verbs that is used to describe a past event that has an influence on the present, which is not the case in this context.

D.Choice: has caused uneven heat flow and has limited

Key.Rationale: “Has caused” and “has limited” are also singular verbs.  Additionally, this choice is a present perfect tense verbs that is used to describe a past event that has an influence on the present, which is not the case in this context.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L5 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is redundant. There is no reason to repeat the idea of “specially designed.”
This choice is redundant. There is no reason to repeat the idea of “specially designed.”
This choice is redundant. There is no reason to repeat the idea of “specially designed.”
The emphasized portion should be deleted because “built for this purpose” repeats the idea of being “specially designed” used previously in the sentence.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L6 of the passage.
Which revision provides the most effective transition between ideas in the paragraph?

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't link the previously identified problems with the specific solution: a program that could help the students overcome too little microgravity time and too small droplets.

B.Choice: The UCSD group sought to overcome these difficulties by participating in NASA's Microgravity University program.

Key.Rationale: This choice offers the most effective transition because it links the previously mentioned problems of conducting the biofuel experiment to the UCSD students' solution: participating in NASA's Microgravity University program.

C.Choice: The engineering group realized that aircraft might be the tools they were looking for.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't link the previously identified problems with the specific solution: a program that could help the students overcome too little microgravity time and too small droplets.

D.Choice: Thus, for the UCSD group, drop towers were not an adequate solution.

Key.Rationale: This choice doesn't link the previously identified problems with the specific solution: a program that could help the students overcome too little microgravity time and too small droplets.

Content: Refer to the emphasized portion at location L7 of the passage.
Which revision most effectively improves the quality of writing in the passage or makes the passage conform to the conventions of standard written English.

Key.Rationale: This choice is missing the comma after “weightlessness.” If the information between the commas were removed, the sentence would not make sense.

B.Choice: “weightlessness” or microgravity, similar to what is experienced, in space

Key.Rationale: In this context, this choice is incorrect because the commas are misplaced. If the information between the commas were removed, the sentence would not make sense.

C.Choice: “weightlessness” or, microgravity, similar to what is experienced in space

Key.Rationale: In this context, this choice is incorrect because the commas are misplaced. If the information between the commas were removed, the sentence would not make sense.

D.Choice: “weightlessness,” or microgravity similar to what is experienced in space,
